org.jgentleframework.services.objectpooling.annotation
Annotation Type SystemPooling

@Retention(value=RUNTIME)
@Target(value=TYPE)
public @interface SystemPooling

This annotation provides all the configuration parameters that affect the pooling service.

Author:
Quoc Chung - mailto: skydunkpro@yahoo.com

Optional Element Summary
 byte exhaustedActionType
          If the Pooling.MaxPoolSize() value has been reached for a pool (no more objects are available to be borrowed), this parameter specifies the action to be taken when a request for an object is made to the pool.

 int maxIdle
          The property is used to configure the maximum number of objects that can be in the pool at any given time.
 long minEvictableIdleTime
          This property specifies the minimum time in milliseconds that objects can stay in a pool.
 int minIdle
          The default minimum number of "sleeping" instances in the pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.
 int numTestsPerEvictionRun
          This property limits the number of objects to examine in each eviction run, if such a thread is running.
 long softMinEvictableIdleTime
          The minimum amount of time an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor (if any), with the extra condition that at least "minIdle" amount of object remain in the pool.
 boolean testOnObtain
          When true, object beans will be validated before being returned by the PoolType.obtainObject() method.

          This property indicates to the eviction thread (if such a thread is running) that objects must be tested when they’re sitting idle in the pool.
 long timeBetweenEvictionRuns
          This property controls the spawning of a thread and the time between its active runs.
 

exhaustedActionType

public abstract byte exhaustedActionType
If the Pooling.MaxPoolSize() value has been reached for a pool (no more objects are available to be borrowed), this parameter specifies the action to be taken when a request for an object is made to the pool.

- EXHAUSTED_FAIL (byte value of 0) - The caller is told that no objects are available, by throwing the exception NoSuchElementException.

- EXHAUSTED_BLOCK (byte value of 1) - The caller waits until an object is returned to the pool and becomes available. The length of time the caller waits is specified by the maxWait property. If this property is negative, the caller waits indefinitely. If no object is available even after the wait is over, a NoSuchElementException exception is thrown.

- EXHAUSTED_GROW (byte value of 2) - The pool automatically grows (it creates a new object and returns it to the caller).

The default setting for this parameter is EXHAUSTED_BLOCK

Default:
1

LIFO

public abstract boolean LIFO
The pool can be configured to behave as a LIFO queue with respect to idle objects - always returning the most recently used object from the pool, or as a FIFO queue, where borrowObject always returns the oldest object in the idle object pool. The lifo determines whether or not the pool returns idle objects in last-in-first-out order.

The default setting for this parameter is false.

Default:
false

maxIdle

public abstract int maxIdle
The property is used to configure the maximum number of objects that can be in the pool at any given time. If a caller tries to return an object to the pool and the pool already contains the maximum number of objects sitting idle, specified by this property, the returned object is rejected.

As with Pooling.MaxPoolSize(), values should be greater than or equal to 0. A negative value implies no limit on the number of objects that can stay idle in the pool.

The default setting for this parameter is 8.

Default:
8

minEvictableIdleTime

public abstract long minEvictableIdleTime
This property specifies the minimum time in milliseconds that objects can stay in a pool. After this time is up, these objects are eligible to be destroyed, and will be destroyed, the next time the eviction thread is run, as specified by the previous property. You can set a negative value for this property, which stops objects from being destroyed. However, objects can still be destroyed using the next property. Note that this value is reset when a borrowed object is returned to the pool.

This value is in milliseconds and should be greater than 0. A value of 0 or less means that objects aren’t eligible for destruction based on the time they have spent in the pool alone.

The default setting for this parameter is 1800000 milliseconds or half an hour.

Default:
1800000L

minIdle

public abstract int minIdle
The default minimum number of "sleeping" instances in the pool before the evictor thread (if active) spawns new objects.

Default:
0

numTestsPerEvictionRun

public abstract int numTestsPerEvictionRun
This property limits the number of objects to examine in each eviction run, if such a thread is running. This allows you to enforce a kind of random check on the idle objects, rather than a fullscale check (which, if the number of idle objects is large, can be processor intensive).

This value should be 0 or greater. If it’s 0, then of course, no objects will be examined. However, if you supply a negative value, you can enable fractional checking. Thus, if you supply a value of -2, it tells the evictor thread to examine 1/2 objects (roughly).

The default setting for this parameter is 3.

Default:
3

softMinEvictableIdleTime

public abstract long softMinEvictableIdleTime
The minimum amount of time an object may sit idle in the pool before it is eligible for eviction by the idle object evictor (if any), with the extra condition that at least "minIdle" amount of object remain in the pool. When non-positive, no objects will be evicted from the pool due to idle time alone.

Default:
-1L

testOnObtain

public abstract boolean testOnObtain
When true, object beans will be validated before being returned by the PoolType.obtainObject() method. If the object fails to validate, it will be dropped from the pool, and we will attempt to borrow another.

Default:
true

testWhileIdle

public abstract boolean testWhileIdle
This property indicates to the eviction thread (if such a thread is running) that objects must be tested when they’re sitting idle in the pool. They’re tested by calling the validateObject method if it existed. It’s up to the validating method to decide how objects are validated. Invalidated objects are destroyed by calling the destroyObject method.

The default setting for this parameter is false.

See Also:
Validate
Default:
false

timeBetweenEvictionRuns

public abstract long timeBetweenEvictionRuns
This property controls the spawning of a thread and the time between its active runs. This thread can examine idle objects in the pool and destroy these objects to conserve system resources. A negative or 0 value for this property ensures that no such thread is started. Even if such a thread is started, your objects can be prevented from being evicted by using the minEvictableIdleTime() property.

This value is in milliseconds and should be greater than 0. A value of 0 or less ensures that this thread isn’t started.

The default setting for this parameter is -1 (eviction thread isn’t started by default).

Default:
-1L
